pullrequest.title: Fixes for YTArray subclasses and adding HDF5 I/O for YTArray.

content.raw: This construction is not efficient for many writes.  While I don't believe that will come into play here, in other places you should consider doing an in-place replacement operation if the datasets are the same shape/size.  Removing the dataset in HDF5 won't result in a repack operation.
content.html: This construction is not efficient for many writes. While I don't believe that will come into play here, in other places you should consider doing an in-place replacement operation if the datasets are the same shape/size. Removing the dataset in HDF5 won't result in a repack operation.

pullrequest.title: Fixes for YTArray subclasses and adding HDF5 I/O for YTArray.

content.raw: I can't find a canonical reference for this, but I'm pretty sure `is` is the correct comparison here as the python interpreter only keeps track of one instance of a class type object.  Note that `ret_class` is generated by calling the `type` function on line 902 or 903 above.
content.html: I can't find a canonical reference for this, but I'm pretty sure is is the correct comparison here as the python interpreter only keeps track of one instance of a class type object. Note that ret_class is generated by calling the type function on line 902 or 903 above.

Ah -- don't feel obliged to do this, then, I don't mean to make work for you.  But here is an example:

```
if dataset_name in f and f[dataset_name].shape == self.shape and f[dataset_name].dtype == self.dtype:
    f[dataset_name][:] = self
```

content.raw: Unfortunately it doesn't present a nice dict-like interface, at least as far as I can tell.  I originally tried to do `if 'unit_registry' in dataset.attrs` on line 540, but that doesn't work, so I had to explicitly call `keys()`.

pullrequest.title: Fixes for YTArray subclasses and adding HDF5 I/O for YTArray.

content.raw: Okay.  But one followup question -- why do we need the full LUT?  Why not just the unit, and a to_cgs conversion?
content.html: Okay. But one followup question -- why do we need the full LUT? Why not just the unit, and a to_cgs conversion?

pullrequest.title: Fixes for YTArray subclasses and adding HDF5 I/O for YTArray.

content.raw:
We could, but then we'd lose the rest of the unit registry.  If someone wanted to (for some reason) save the array to disk, load it, and then convert to code units, they would get an error.

If we don't want to allow that, I can make it so we only save the CGS conversion rather that then full LUT.

FWIW, we also save the full LUT when we pickle YTArray instances.
content.html:
We could, but then we'd lose the rest of the unit registry. If someone wanted to (for some reason) save the array to disk, load it, and then convert to code units, they would get an error.

If we don't want to allow that, I can make it so we only save the CGS conversion rather that then full LUT.

FWIW, we also save the full LUT when we pickle YTArray instances.

pullrequest.title: Fixes for YTArray subclasses and adding HDF5 I/O for YTArray.

content.raw: Okay, fair enough.  I am broadly -1 on pickling in non-pickle files, but we can evaluate if it's worth using a JSON-ifier.  Again, not trying to make work for you.
content.html: Okay, fair enough. I am broadly -1 on pickling in non-pickle files, but we can evaluate if it's worth using a JSON-ifier. Again, not trying to make work for you.

content.raw: I'm not sure I understand this.  Specifically, you want to return the opposite class, if one is ndarray or numeric?
content.html: I'm not sure I understand this. Specifically, you want to return the opposite class, if one is ndarray or numeric?

pullrequest.title: Fixes for YTArray subclasses and adding HDF5 I/O for YTArray.

content.raw:
That's right.  For example:

```
#!python

a = YTArray([1,2,3], 'cm')
b = 3

assert_isinstance(a*b, YTArray)
```

Or, more generally:

```
class YTASubclass(YTArray):
    pass

a = YTASubclass([1,2,3], 'cm')
b = 3

assert_isinstance(a*b, YTASubclass)
```

This works because of the code on line 1026 and 1028 below.  We can never have a situation where both input classes are numeric, since at least one of them have to be a `YTArray` subclass to end up in `YTArray`'s `__array_wrap__` function.
content.html:
That's right. For example:

a = YTArray([1,2,3], 'cm')
b = 3

assert_isinstance(a*b, YTArray)

Or, more generally:

class YTASubclass(YTArray):
    pass

a = YTASubclass([1,2,3], 'cm')
b = 3

assert_isinstance(a*b, YTASubclass)

This works because of the code on line 1026 and 1028 below. We can never have a situation where both input classes are numeric, since at least one of them have to be a YTArray subclass to end up in YTArray's __array_wrap__ function.

pullrequest.title: Fixes for YTArray subclasses and adding HDF5 I/O for YTArray.

content.raw:
I agree that pickling isn't great and it's definitely a big shortcut here to avoid writing a bunch more code to more properly serialize unit metadata.

The reason I didn't save the unit metadata as individual entries in the `attrs` namespace is that I'd run into trouble if someone also passed an `info` dict, since I wouldn't be able to tell the difference between `unit_registry` entries and metadata from the `info` dict. I could create a new dataset to store the unit metadata, but then what do I do if someone tries to write two arrays to the same hdf5 file? Another option would be to write the data to an HDF5 group, but then I'd break backwards compatibility with the `ImageArray` `write_hdf5` function.

My approach in this PR is to instead save all of the unit metadata in a single entry in the `attrs` namespace.  Unfortunately, h5py only knows about numpy dtypes, so it doesn't natively save dictionaries. Worse, the `unit_registry` contains sympy objects, so it's even more challenging to serialize in a format that doesn't natively know about python objects like `pickle`. This is a deficiency in the design of YTArray and it's something I want to improve, but that probably goes beyond the scope of this PR.

A better choice might be to serialize the unit metadata as a json string. That will require serializing and deserializing the `sympy` objects we're currently using to store dimensionality data in the unit registry into some json-compatible format.  If we figure out how to do that we might also be able to get some memory savings for `YTArray` overall, since the `unit_registry` carries around a `sympy` object for each entry in the lookup table and we might be able to get the same effect carrying around a string instead. That said, I don't think unit registries are a big memory cost for us, since most arrays only carry around a reference to a `unit_registry` owned by a dataset object or to the `default_unit_registry` object.
content.html:
I agree that pickling isn't great and it's definitely a big shortcut here to avoid writing a bunch more code to more properly serialize unit metadata.

The reason I didn't save the unit metadata as individual entries in the attrs namespace is that I'd run into trouble if someone also passed an info dict, since I wouldn't be able to tell the difference between unit_registry entries and metadata from the info dict. I could create a new dataset to store the unit metadata, but then what do I do if someone tries to write two arrays to the same hdf5 file? Another option would be to write the data to an HDF5 group, but then I'd break backwards compatibility with the ImageArray write_hdf5 function.

My approach in this PR is to instead save all of the unit metadata in a single entry in the attrs namespace. Unfortunately, h5py only knows about numpy dtypes, so it doesn't natively save dictionaries. Worse, the unit_registry contains sympy objects, so it's even more challenging to serialize in a format that doesn't natively know about python objects like pickle. This is a deficiency in the design of YTArray and it's something I want to improve, but that probably goes beyond the scope of this PR.

A better choice might be to serialize the unit metadata as a json string. That will require serializing and deserializing the sympy objects we're currently using to store dimensionality data in the unit registry into some json-compatible format. If we figure out how to do that we might also be able to get some memory savings for YTArray overall, since the unit_registry carries around a sympy object for each entry in the lookup table and we might be able to get the same effect carrying around a string instead. That said, I don't think unit registries are a big memory cost for us, since most arrays only carry around a reference to a unit_registry owned by a dataset object or to the default_unit_registry object.

pullrequest.title: Fixes for YTArray subclasses and adding HDF5 I/O for YTArray.

description:
This PR includes:

1. Fixes and tests for subclassing `YTArray`.  I'd love it if someone could carefully look over the truth tables to pass the `test_subclass` function and verify that I'm doing the correct thing in all cases.

2. Adding hdf5 i/o to YTArray.  This functionality is stolen from `image_array`, which now outsources to `YTArray` for this functionality.  As a bonus the units of the array are written to disk as an attribute along with a string containing a `pickle` serialization of the unit registry dictionary. I had to use `pickle` since there is no support in `h5py` for writing dictionaries and I didn't want to create a whole dataset or group just for the unit registry.

3. Whitespace and pep8 cleanups for image_array.py.
